question: It's a good day for the crows.
answer: I told you yesterday and I'll tell you again today. Remove your army from my land. Agamemnon smiles again and turns to examine the valley.

question: I like your land. I think we'll stay. I like your soldiers, too. They fought bravely yesterday. Not well, but bravely.
answer: They'll never fight for you.

question: That's what the Messenians said, too. And the Arcadians. And the Epeians. They're all fighting for me, now.
answer: You can't rule the whole world, Agamemnon. It's too big. Even for you.

question: I don't want to watch another massacre. Let's end this war in the old manner. Your best fighter against my best. For the first time, Triopas looks hopeful.
answer: And if my man wins?

question: We'll leave Thessaly for good. I'm a generous man. If mine wins, you keep your throne. But Thessaly falls under my command, to fight with me whenever I call. Triopas considers before nodding. He shouts to his army.
answer: Boagrius! The Thessalonians murmur and step aside. A giant emerges from their midst, BOAGRIUS, a foot taller than the other men, his face gouged with old knife scars. He marches out to his king. Here is my champion. Agamemnon raises his eyebrows as the giant comes closer.

question: Achilles! The Mycenaeans murmur amongst themselves, looking for Achilles. Nobody emerges. Agamemnon frowns.
answer: Boagrius has this effect on many heroes.

question: Shh. The boy stares into the eyes of ACHILLES , who seems to have barely moved. Somehow he managed to seize the boy and put a knife to his throat without waking the women. I was having a good dream. A very good dream. The boy nods, dumb with fear. Achilles has the lean, efficient physique of a boxer. His face and body are dark from a summer spent in the sun.
answer: King Agamemnon sent me. He needs --

question: I'll speak with your king in the morning.
answer: But my lord -- it is morning. Achilles frowns. He stands and walks naked to the tent flap, holds it open and stares at the empty encampment. They're waiting for you. Are the stories about you true? They say your mother is an immortal goddess. They say you can't be killed.

question: I wouldn't be bothering with the shield then, would I?
answer: The Thessalonian you're fighting -- he's the biggest man I've ever seen. Achilles mounts the boy's horse. I wouldn't want to fight him.

question: Princes of Troy, on our last night together, Queen Helen and I salute you. We've had our conflicts before, it's true. We've fought many battles, Sparta and Troy. And fought well! But I've always respected your father. Priam is a good man, a good king. I respected him as an adversary, and I respect him now as my ally. Hector, Paris, young princes, come, stand, drink with me. Hector stands. Paris does not. He's still staring at Helen. Hector nudges his brother's shoulder. Paris stands. Let us drink to peace. Hector nods to Menelaus and raises his cup.
answer: Peace between Troy and Sparta.

question: May the gods keep the wolves in the hills and the women in our beds. All the men in the hall cheer and rise to their feet. A strong arm. Thank the gods we made peace -- I've seen too many of my men struck down with this arm.
answer: Never again, I hope.

question: Only one man works a sword better than you. The son of Peleus the Argonaut.
answer: Achilles.

question: That madman would throw a spear at Zeus himself if the god insulted him. You see that one over there? I picked her just for you. She's a little lioness. Menelaus grins at the girl, who lowers her eyes and smiles. Helen notices this silent exchange but ignores it, conversing instead with another HANDMAIDEN who sits beside her.
answer: Thank you. My wife waits for me in Troy.

question: My wife waits for me right there. He leans forward to whisper conspiratorially in Hector's ear. Wives are for breeding. You understand? For making little princes. Come, enjoy yourself tonight. Helen stands and walks out of the reception hall. Menelaus does not notice. Hector does. He raises his cup to Menelaus.
answer: You make excellent wine in Sparta. Menelaus laughs and drinks with Hector. Paris excuses himself from the Spartan generals he's been speaking with and heads outside -- in the same direction as Helen. Hector watches with mounting agitation.

question: You shouldn't be here. Paris closes the door behind him.
answer: That's what you said last night.

question: Last night was a mistake.
answer: And the night before? Helen continues removing the flowers from her hair but she cannot hide a half-smile.

question: I've made many mistakes this week. He approaches her.
answer: Do you want me to go? His hands are on her now, sliding down her bare neck, down her back, resting on her hips. His mouth is very close to her ear. Helen closes her eyes.

question: Yes. Paris kisses her neck, her ears, her closed eyes. The tightness we saw in her face when she sat by her husband's side is gone, replaced by ecstasy.
answer: Where should I go? She kisses him back now and there's a hunger in her kisses, something close to violence in her desire. She lifts off his tunic and pulls him nearer.

question: Away. Far away. In a moment the white gown slips to her feet. He stares at her naked body in wonder. He opens his mouth to speak but she kisses him full on the lips. They sink onto the bed.
answer: I have something for you. From his tunic he pulls a necklace of baby pearls threaded with silver. He sits beside her in bed. Pearls from the sea of Propontis. Paris strings the pearls around her neck.

question: They're beautiful. But I can't wear them. Menelaus would kill us both.
answer: Don't be afraid of him.

question: I'm not afraid of dying. I'm afraid of tomorrow, watching you sail away and knowing you'll never come back. She runs her fingers across his jaw line. Before you came to Sparta I was a ghost. I walked and I ate and I swam in the sea, but I was a ghost.
answer: You don't have to fear tomorrow. Helen watches him, unsure what he means. Come with me. For a long moment they stare into each other's eyes.

question: Don't play with me, prince of Troy. Don't play. The sounds of footsteps and laughter outside the door startle them. Paris halfway unsheathes a KNIFE hanging from his belt. Whoever's walking by the door passes without stopping. Paris sheathes his knife, kneels beside the bed and takes her hand.
answer: If you come we'll never be safe. Men will hunt us and the gods will curse us. But I'll love you. Until the day they burn my body I will love you. Helen stares into Paris' eyes, contemplating the impossible.

question: Make the proper offerings to Poseidon before we sail. We don't need any more widows in Troy.
answer: Goat or pig?

question: Which does the Sea God prefer?
answer: I'll wake the priest and ask him.

question: Paris! Paris turns, smiles and waves, acting as if he hadn't seen Hector before. He ambles over to join his brother. You should get to bed. We won't sleep on land again for weeks.
answer: I have no trouble sleeping on the seas. The sea nymphs sing lullabies to me.

question: And who sang lullabies to you tonight? Paris freezes for a moment but quickly regains his poise.
answer: Tonight? Tonight was the fisherman's wife. A lovely creature.

question: I hope you didn't let the fisherman catch you.
answer: He's more concerned with the fish. Paris smiles and starts to walk away but Hector holds him.

question: You do understand why we're in Sparta?
answer: For peace.

question: And you do understand that Menelaus, King of Sparta, is a powerful man? And that his brother, Agamemnon, King of Mycenae, commands all the Greek forces?
answer: What does this have to do with the fisherman's wife? Hector seizes Paris's face between the palms of his hand. Not a violent gesture, exactly, but not gentle, either.

question: Paris. You're my brother, and I love you. But if you do anything to endanger Troy I'll rip your pretty face from your pretty skull. He kisses Paris on the forehead. Get some sleep. We sail in the morning. Paris, a bit shocked by the encounter, stumbles away.
answer: A beautiful morning. Poseidon has blessed our voyage. Hector looks at the blue sky for a moment.

question: Sometimes the gods bless you in the morning and curse you in the afternoon.
answer: Do you love me, brother? Hector rests his knife on the deck and smiles.

question: What have you done now?
answer: I need to show you something. Paris walks toward the staircase leading inside the ship. Hector watches him for a few seconds and then follows. Before you get angry with me --

question: Open the door. Paris opens the door. Helen, wearing a hooded robe, sits on the edge of a hammock, swinging slightly. She stands. Hector stares at her in disbelief. He turns and glares at Paris. If you weren't my brother I'd kill you where you stand.
answer: Hector -- Hector is already out the door. Helen looks at Paris.

question: Turn us around. Back to Sparta.
answer: Wait, wait. Hector spins on his brother.

question: You fool.
answer: Listen to me -- Hector shoves his brother backwards. The older brother's physical power is obvious. SAILORS watch in awed silence.

question: Do you know what you've done? Do you know how many years our father worked for peace? How many brothers and cousins he lost on the battlefield?
answer: I love her. The muscles in Hector's jaw bulge against his cheeks.

question: Say another word and I'll break your arm. This is all a game for you, isn't it? You roam from town to town, bedding merchants' wives and temple maids - - you think you know something about love? What about your father's love? You spat on him when you brought her on this ship. What about love of your country? You'd let Troy burn for this woman. Paris starts to speak but Hector raises a warning finger. I won't let you start a war for her.
answer: May I speak? What you say is true. I've wronged you. I've wronged our father. If you want to bring Helen back to Sparta, so be it. But I go with her.

question: To Sparta? They'll kill you.
answer: Then I'll die fighting. Hector laughs bitterly. He grabs the collar of Paris's tunic.

question: That sounds heroic to you, doesn't it? To die fighting. Tell me, little brother, have you ever killed a man?
answer: No.

question: Have you ever even seen a man die in combat?
answer: No. Hector's face is flushed with anger. Paris tries to look away but Hector won't let him.

question: I've killed men, brother. I've watched them dying, I've heard them dying, I've smelled them dying. There's nothing glorious about it, nothing poetic. You think you want to die for love, but you know nothing about dying. You know nothing about love.
answer: All the same, I go with her. Hector releases his brother. He stares at the sea. I won't ask you to fight my war. Hector shakes his head, still staring into the waves.

question: Your messenger came two days ago. I know what happened. Menelaus's face darkens, his rage barely submerged.
answer: I want her back.

question: Of course you do. She's a beautiful woman.
answer: I want her back so I can kill her with my own two hands. I won't rest until I've burned Troy to the ground.

question: I thought you wanted peace with Troy.
answer: I should have listened to you.

question: Peace is for the women and the weak. Empires are forged by war.
answer: All my life I've stood by your side, fought your enemies. You're the eldest, you reap the glory -- this is the way of the world. But have I ever complained, brother? Have I ever asked you for anything?

question: Never. You're a man of honor. Everyone in Greece knows this.
answer: The Trojans spat on my honor. An insult to me is an insult to you.

question: And an insult to me is an insult to all Greeks.
answer: Will you go to war with me, brother? Menelaus reaches out his hand. Agamemnon looks into his eyes. Finally he nods and clasps hands with his brother.

question: I always thought my brother's wife was a foolish woman. But she's proven to be very useful. Nothing unifies a people like a common enemy.
answer: The Trojans have never been conquered. Some say they can't be conquered.

question: I haven't tried yet. Old King Priam thinks he's untouchable behind his high walls. He thinks the Sun God will protect him. But the gods only protect the strong. If Troy falls, I control the Aegean.
answer: Hector commands the finest army in the east. And Troy is built to withstand a ten-year siege.

question: There won't be a ten-year siege. I'll attack them with the greatest force the world has ever seen. I want all the kings of Greece and all their armies. Send emissaries in the morning. Nestor stands and prepares to leave.
answer: One last thing. We need Achilles and his Myrmidons. Agamemnon shakes his head.

question: Achilles can't be controlled. He's as likely to fight us as the Trojans.
answer: We don't need to control him. We need to unleash him. The man was born to end lives.

question: Yes, he's a gifted killer, but he follows no king. He threatens everything I've built. Before me Greece was nothing, a province of warlords and cattle raiders. I've brought all the Greek kingdoms together -- with the sword when necessary, with a treaty when possible. I've created a nation out of fire-worshippers and snake-eaters. I build the future, Nestor. Achilles is the past, a man who fights for no flag, a man loyal to no country. Nestor waits a respectful moment before replying.
answer: Your words are true. But how many battles have we won off the edge of his sword? This will be the greatest war the world has ever seen. We need the greatest warrior. Agamemnon thinks about it, pacing the room. Finally --

question: There's only one man he'll listen to.
answer: I'll send a ship in the morning.

question: You're getting fat, cousin. Patroclus grins and relaunches his attack, sword spinning with blazing speed. Achilles ducks beneath an arcing swing and sword-taps Patroclus on the back. Fancy swordplay. The girls must be impressed. Patroclus grunts and charges in again. This time a genuine duel develops, featuring splendid repartee and parrying.
answer: A little nervous, aren't you?

question: Terrified. Achilles raises his right hand and Patroclus lifts his sword to parry the blow -- but Achilles no longer holds his sword in his right hand. Sword in hisleft hand, Achilles taps Patroclus on the chest. Patroclus stares down at the wood blade.
answer: You told me never to switch sword hands. Achilles rolls his head to loosen his neck.

question: By the time you know how to do it, you won't be following my orders anymore. Achilles tosses aside the sparring sword. He cocks his head as if listening to some distant sound. Patroclus, oblivious to the noise, practices his swordplay. Achilles' foot curls around the wood shaft of one of the spears lying on the ground. In one impossibly fast motion, he flips the spear into the air with his foot, catches it, and throws in the opposite direction from where he was looking.
answer: Your reputation for hospitality is fast becoming legend.

question: I don't like that smile, my friend. It's the smile you smile when you want me to fight in another war. Patroclus, my cousin -- Odysseus, king of Ithaca.
answer: Patroclus, son of Menoetius? The boy nods. Odysseus grips Patroclus's shoulder. I knew your parents well. I miss them. Patroclus nods again, looking at his feet. Now you have this one watching over you, eh? Learning from Achilles himself -- every boy in Greece must be jealous. We need to talk.

question: Tell me you're not here at Agamemnon's bidding. Odysseus hesitates. Achilles shakes his head. How many times have I done the savage work for the King of Kings? And when has he ever shown me the respect I've earned?
answer: I'm not asking you to fight for him. I'm asking you to fight for the Greeks.

question: Why? Are the Greeks tired of fighting each other?
answer: For now.

question: The Trojans never did anything to me.
answer: They insulted Greece.

question: They insulted one Greek, a man who couldn't hold on to his wife. What business is that of mine?
answer: Your business is war, my friend.

question: Is it? Am I the whore of the battlefield? Can my sword be bought and sold? I don't want to be remembered as a tyrant's mercenary.
answer: Forget Agamemnon. Fight for me. My wife will feel much better if she knows you're by my side. I'll feel much better.

question: Mother. Thetis turns and smiles at Achilles.
answer: I thought I'd make you another seashell necklace.

question: I haven't worn a seashell necklace since I was a boy. Thetis looks at Achilles' bare neck.
answer: Don't you like them anymore? Achilles spots a good shell. He hands it to his mother. Oh, that's a pretty one. She surveys the beach for more pretty shells.

question: They want me for another war. Thetis bends down and scoops up a silvery shell. Are you listening?
answer: Yes, my sweet. Another war.

question: Patroclus wants to go.
answer: Patroclus has never seen war. If you stay here, with me, with your family, you'll have a long, peaceful life. You'll marry, you'll have children, and your children will have children. They'll love you, and when you're gone they'll remember you. But when your children are dead, and their children after them, your name will be lost. Thetis reaches up to touch her son's cheek. Her eyes are clear, her voice steady. She speaks these lines with no hesitation, no doubt. If you go to Troy, no one will earn more glory than you. Men will tell stories of your victories for thousands of years. The world will remember your name. Achilles stares at her, his eyes burning. These are words he's wanted to hear since the day he was born. His mother waits a moment before speaking again. The words hurt her. But if you go to Troy, you'll never come home. You'll die there.

question: And you know this, mother?
answer: I know it. Achilles looks out to the sea. Thetis, tears in her eyes, smiles bravely. Whenever your father came home from war, he'd stare at the sea, just like that. He never stayed for long. In the distance Achilles sees a white sail. He fixates on the lonely spot of white on the endless expanse of dark water.

question: I thank the gods for your safe return. The king and the princes spill a few drops of wine. It's the will of the gods. Everything is in their hands. But I'm surprised you let him bring her.
answer: If I'd let him fight Menelaus for her, you'd be burning a son's body instead of welcoming a daughter. Priam closes his eyes at these words.

question: We could send peace envoys to Menelaus.
answer: You know Menelaus. He'd spear your envoys' heads to his gate.

question: What would you have me do?
answer: Put her on a ship and send her home. Priam thinks for a moment, staring out at his city.

question: Women have always loved Paris and he's loved them back. But this is different. Something has changed in him. If we send her back to Menelaus, he'll follow. Hector stands and joins his father in the archway. He gestures outside. The city of Troy teems with life, the CITIZENS going about their business.
answer: This is my country. These are my countrymen. I don't want to see them suffer so my brother can have his prize. It's not just the Spartans coming after her. By now Menelaus has gone to Agamemnon, and Agamemnon's wanted to destroy us for years. Once we're out of the way he controls the seas.

question: Enemies have been attacking us for centuries. Our walls still stand.
answer: Father. We can't win this war.

question: Apollo watches over us. Even Agamemnon is no match for the gods.
answer: How many battalions does the Sun God command?

question: Don't mock the gods. Hector opens his mouth to argue but holds his tongue. When you were very young you came down with scarlet fever. Hector nods impatiently. He's heard this story before. Your little hands were so hot. The healer said you wouldn't last the night. I went down to Apollo's temple and I prayed until the sun came up. That walk back to the palace was the longest of my life. But I went into your mother's room and you were sleeping in her arms. The fever had broken. I promised that day to dedicate my life to the gods. I will not break my promise. For thirty years I've worked for peace. Thirty years. Paris is a fool sometimes. I know that. But I'll fight a thousand wars before letting him die. Hector looks past the city to the sea. The waters are empty now, but he knows what's coming.
answer: Forgive me, father. But you won't be the one fighting. He bows and leaves the old king alone in the great hall.

question: They're coming for me. The wind is bringing them closer. Paris stops pacing and stares at her.
answer: What if we left? Tonight, right now, what if we went down to the stables, took two horses and left. Ride east, keep riding --

question: And go where?
answer: Away from here. I could hunt deer, rabbit. I could feed us.

question: This is your home --
answer: You left your home for me.

question: Sparta was never my home. My parents sent me there when I was sixteen to marry Menelaus, but it was never my home. Paris, excited with his new-hatched plan, barely listens.
answer: We'll live off the land. No more palaces for us, no more servants. We don't need any of that.

question: And your family?
answer: We'd be protecting my family! If we're not here there's no need for a war.

question: Menelaus won't give up. He'll track us to the end of the world.
answer: He doesn't know these lands. I do. We can lose ourselves in a day. Helen stands and kisses him on the lips.

question: You don't know Menelaus. You don't know his brother. They'll burn every house in Troy to find us. They'll never believe we've left -- and even if they do, they'll burn Troy for spite. Paris considers her words and finally nods.
answer: Then I'll make it easy for him to find me. I'll walk right up to him and tell him you're mine. Helen wraps her arms around Paris and rests her chin on his shoulder.

question: You're very young, my love.
answer: We're the same age!

question: Should we wait for the others? Achilles marks the progress of the other ships. The nearest is a quarter-mile back. Those MYRMIDONS not rowing are suiting up for battle.
answer: They brought us here for a war, didn't they?

question: Yes, my lord. But Agamemnon -- Achilles stares at his officer until the man bows his head.
answer: Do you fight for me, Eudorus? Or Agamemnon?

question: For you, my lord.
answer: Then fight for me. And let the servants of Agamemnon fight for him.

question: Where are you going?
answer: To fight the Trojans. Achilles shakes his head and takes Patroclus' spear.

question: You're not ready.
answer: I am ready. You taught me how to fight. Achilles rests his hand on the back of the boy's head.

question: The temple is secure.
answer: The Sun God is the patron of Troy, our enemy. Take whatever treasure you can find. The Myrmidons cheer and rush the temple.

question: With your permission, my lord --
answer: Speak. Eudorus gestures to the sun above them.

question: You must be very brave or very stupid, to come after me alone. You must be Hector. Hector stares at Achilles a moment before kneeling by the dead priests' bodies. A private audience with the prince of Troy. I'm flattered. Do you know who I am?
answer: These priests weren't armed. Hector closes the eyes of the murdered priests. Achilles jumps down from the altar and looks at the bodies.

question: I didn't kill them. Cutting old men's throats -- there's no honor in that.
answer: Honor? Children and fools fight for honor. I fight for my country. Hector charges. Achilles dances back, staying just out of reach. Achilles looks relaxed, almost playful. Fight me.

question: Why kill you, prince of Troy, with no one here to see you fall? Achilles backs out of an archway opening onto the bright day outside. Hector follows.
answer: Why did you come here?

question: They'll be talking about this war for a thousand years.
answer: In a thousand years even the dust from our bones will be gone.

question: It's too early in the day for killing princes.
answer: Achilles! Achilles halts. For a moment there seems to be tension in the air. Everyone watches. Ajax gives Achilles a bear hug. You're as fearless as a god.

question: The gods are immortal. What do they have to fear? Ajax laughs and releases Achilles.
answer: I'm honored to go to war with you. Achilles nods and grips the big man's thick arm.

question: Leave us. Eudorus bows and exits. Achilles pulls a small, sharp knife from his belt. Briseis stares at the blade. Achilles walks over to her and cuts the ropes that bind her. She sits back, rubbing the chafed skin of her wrists, still watching Achilles. He sheathes his knife. What's your name? Briseis stares at him but doesn't answer. Achilles becomes aware, for the first time, that he's covered in blood. He wipes a hand across his face. Briseis looks about the tent, as if searching for a way out. You're safer in this tent than out there. Believe me.
answer: You killed Apollo's priests.

question: I've killed men in five countries. But never a priest.
answer: Then your men did. The Sun God will have his vengeance. Achilles removes his bronze grieves.

question: What's he waiting for? Briseis is stunned by such blunt blasphemy but she can't take her eyes off him, because Achilles, after all, is Achilles.
answer: The right time to strike.

question: His priests are dead and his acolyte's a captive. I think your god is afraid of me. Briseis laughs bitterly.
answer: Afraid? Apollo is master of the sun. He fears nothing. Achilles nods and looks around the dark tent.

question: Then where is he? Briseis has no answer. Achilles smiles and she looks away. A bucket of hot water sits beside a washcloth. Achilles wets the cloth and begins to scrub the blood from his body.
answer: You're nothing but a killer. You don't know anything about the gods.

question: You haven't seen twenty summers and you think you know my heart? I know more about the gods than priests could ever teach you. You're royalty, aren't you? Briseis says nothing. Achilles smiles again. You've spent years talking down to men, you must be royalty. What's your name? Even the servants of Apollo have names.
answer: Briseis.

question: Are you afraid, Briseis? Briseis is quiet for a moment. She watches Achilles with a mixture of fear and curiosity.
answer: Should I be?

question: My lord --
answer: What is it? Eudorus sticks his head inside the tent.

question: King Agamemnon requests your presence.
answer: Why would I want to look at him when I can look at her?

question: All the kings are there, celebrating the victory. Achilles stands.
answer: Give me a moment. Eudorus withdraws. A long beat while Achilles studies her. You don't need to fear me, girl. You're the only Trojan who can say that.

question: Leave us. The aides exit, leaving Achilles and Agamemnon alone. Achilles eyes the pile of gifts.
answer: Apparently you've won some great victory.

question: Ah, perhaps you didn't notice. The Trojan beach belonged to Priam in the morning. It belongs to Agamemnon in the afternoon.
answer: You can have the beach. I didn't come here for sand.

question: No, you came because you want your name to last through the ages. A great victory was won today -- but the victory is not yours. Kings did not kneel to Achilles. Kings did not bring homage to Achilles.
answer: The battle was won by soldiers. The soldiers know who fought.

question: History remembers the kings, not the soldiers. Tomorrow we'll batter down the gates of Troy. I'll build monuments to victory on every island of Greece, and carve Agamemnon in the stone. My name will last forever. Your name is written in the sand, for the waves to wash away.
answer: First you need the victory.

question: One more thing, son of Peleus.
answer: I don't want to hear my father's name from your mouth.

question: The first pick of the battle's spoils always goes to the commander. Your men sacked the temple of Apollo, yes?
answer: You want gold? Take it, it's my gift, to honor your courage. Take what you want.

question: I already have. Aphareus! Haemon! Two battle-scarred soldiers, APHAREUS and HAEMON, drag Briseis into the tent. Her face is bruised -- clearly she's been slapped around. The spoils of war. Tonight I'll have her give me a bath. And then -- who knows? Achilles draws his sword.
answer: I have no quarrel with you, brothers. But you'll never see home again if you don't let her go. The soldiers hesitate, then draw their own swords. Achilles advances on them.

question: Father, I... I'm sorry for the pain I've caused you. I --
answer: Do you love her? Paris looks up at the statue of Aphrodite.

question: You're a great king because you love your country so much. Every blade of grass, every grain of sand, every rock in the river -- you love all of Troy. That's the way I love Helen. Priam nods and contemplates the goddess of beauty.
answer: I've fought many wars in my time. Some were fought for land, some for power, some for glory. I suppose fighting for love makes more sense than all the rest. Paris says nothing, but his father's words seem to relieve a great burden from his shoulders. But I won't be the one fighting. He hands Paris the bundle. Paris, curious, begins unwrapping the cloth. Finally the object is uncovered

question: The Sword of Troy.
answer: My father carried this sword, and his father before him, all the way back to the founding of Troy. The history of our people was written with this sword. Carry it with you tomorrow. Paris holds the sword up and it glows in the moonlight. The spirit of Troy is in that sword. As long as a Trojan carries it, our people have a future.

question: He has no idea what's happening.
answer: Thank the gods.

question: The man who killed Tecton outside Apollo's temple -- I've never seen a spear thrown like that. An impossible throw. A long beat until Andromache breaks the silence.
answer: Briseis was in Apollo's temple this morning. Hector stares at Andromache.

question: Are you sure? She nods, swallows hard, and closes her eyes. After a moment Hector, his eyes full of sorrow, runs his hand through her long hair. I need to see my brother.
answer: Don't go.

question: I need to speak with him.
answer: I mean tomorrow. Don't go. You've fought enough. Let other men go out there.

question: You think I want to fight, my love? I want to see my son grow tall. I want to see the girls chasing after him.
answer: Just like they chased his father?

question: He's much more handsome than I ever was.
answer: I lost seven brothers in the Spartan Wars. You'd think I'd be good at losing by now. I can't lose you. I won't survive. Hector stares at her for a beat before pulling her close and kissing her. Everything is in this kiss, their entire past. Andromache finally lets him go and Hector walks out the door.

question: Wait! The cloaked figure looks back and then runs. Hector chases. The fugitive runs through the archway at the end of the corridor and into the garden. Helen? By the light of the moon he examines her face. The stress of recent weeks has taken its toll, but the shadows beneath her eyes make her face more compelling than ever. Embarrassed by the awkwardness of their position, Hector stands and helps Helen to her feet. What are you doing out --
answer: Let me go.

question: Where? Helen struggles against Hector's grip, but it's useless.
answer: Let me go! Helen, still struggling, begins to cry. Hector pulls her to his chest. She cries for real now, violently sobbing, her mouth muffled against Hector's body.

question: Shh. Shh.
answer: I saw them burn. I saw them burning on the pyres. It's my fault.

question: No.
answer: It is. You know it is. All those widows. I still hear them screaming. Helen takes a deep breath. She manages to control herself. Their husbands died because I'm here. Hector can't deny this. Helen pushes herself out of his grip. I'm going down to the ships.

question: No. You're not.
answer: I'll give myself back to Menelaus. He can do what he wants -- kill me, make me his slave. Anything's better than this.

question: It's too late for that. You think Agamemnon cares about his brother's marriage? This is about power. Not love.
answer: Paris is going to fight in the morning.

question: Yes.
answer: Menelaus will kill him. Hector looks away, the words hurting him. I won't let that happen.

question: It's his decision.
answer: No. No. I can't ask anyone to fight for me. I'm no longer queen of Sparta. Hector bows to Helen and kisses her hand.

question: Agamemnon spat on my honor yesterday. I promised that girl her safety and he stole her from me. Let him fight the Trojans today. Eudorus and Patroclus exchange glances. Eudorus bows to Achilles and exits the tent. Patroclus remains behind. When I was very small I saw my father kill a man with his bare hands. Patroclus doesn't know how to respond to this. There's so much blood in a human body. You're ready to fight, Patroclus?
answer: I am. Achilles rests his sword on the ground. He stares at Patroclus for a moment before speaking.

question: You're ready to kill? Patroclus hesitates. At night I see their faces. All the men I've killed. I see them standing on the far bank of the River Styx. They're waiting for me. Patroclus stands absolutely still. He's never heard his cousin speak this way before. Some nights I walk among them. When I wake I can still hear their words. They say, "Welcome, brother." Achilles inspects the knuckles of his fist. Never hate the men you fight. All of us are mortals. All of us, wretched things, tumbled crying from our mother's loins. Only the gods are free from sorrows.
answer: I hate no one, cousin.

question: Good. I taught you how to fight. But I never taught you why to fight.
answer: I fight for you.

question: And who will you follow when I'm gone? Patroclus hesitates, unsure how to answer. Most soldiers battle for kings they've never met. They do what they're told; they die when they're told to die.
answer: Soldiers obey.

question: We don't have much time to walk in the sun, Patroclus. After this life comes the underworld, an eternity telling stories to other shades. Don't tell them you died following some fool's orders.
answer: And what should I tell them?

question: Sit with me. Helen follows the king to his grandstand and sits beside him. She's aware of people staring at them but he seems oblivious. All my life I've prayed against this day.
answer: Yes, my king.

question: Call me father, dear child. Startled by this affection, she hesitates before responding.
answer: Forgive me, father. For... She pauses, staring out at the vast Greek army. ...bringing this. Priam shakes his head and smiles sadly.

question: I have two wishes. If you grant them, no more of your people need to die. First, give Helen back to my brother. Second, Troy must submit to my command, to fight for me whenever I call.
answer: You want me to look upon your army and tremble. Well, I see them. I see fifty thousand men brought here to fight for one man's greed.

question: Be careful, boy. My mercy has limits.
answer: I've seen the limits of your mercy. And I tell you now that no son of Troy will ever submit to a foreign ruler.

question: He doesn't have the stamina he once did. Make him swing and miss. He'll tire. Paris nods. He turns toward Menelaus but quickly turns back and grabs Hector's arm.
answer: Hector! Hector waits. Paris opens his mouth but no words come out. He tries again. If I fall -- tell Helen -- tell her --

question: I will.
answer: Don't let Menelaus hurt her. Make him swear --

question: They're laughing at me in Troy. Old Priam and the others, drunk on victory. They think I'll quit these shores, sail home at first light.
answer: Maybe we should. Agamemnon spins and glares at Odysseus.

question: Flee like a whipped dog?
answer: The men believe we came here for Menelaus's wife. He won't be needing his wife anymore.

question: My brother's blood still wets the grass and you insult him?
answer: It's no insult to say a dead man is dead.

question: You're right. But if we stay, we stay for the right reasons. We stay to protect Greece, not your pride. Your private battle with Achilles is destroying us.
answer: Achilles is one man. What good could he --

question: Hector is one man. Look what he did to us today.
answer: Hector fights for his country. Achilles fights only for himself.

question: Nine. The other soldiers run. Achilles lifts Briseis to her feet. More gently than we would have believed possible, Achilles brushes the sand from her face and hair. Can you walk? Briseis nods. Achilles, arm around her shoulder, leads her away from the campfire. Get me food and water. And a new robe. Eudorus bows. Patroclus watches Achilles and Briseis enter the tent. You should eat. Briseis says nothing. Did they hurt you?
answer: What do you think?

question: I saw you fight them. You have courage.
answer: To fight back when people attack me? A dog has that kind of courage.

question: I like dogs more than people. Briseis stares into Achilles' eyes. He's not used to people meeting his gaze. He stares back at the girl, intrigued.
answer: Why did you choose this life?

question: What life?
answer: This... to be a great warrior.

question: I chose nothing. I was born and this is what I am.
answer: But you must enjoy it.

question: Does the scorpion feel joy when he stings the beetle? I doubt it. I doubt he feels anything at all.
answer: But you're not a scorpion. You're a man.

question: And you're a woman in love with a god. Where was Apollo when those men tried to scar you?
answer: Do you enjoy provoking me?

question: Yes. You've dedicated your life to the gods, yes? Briseis, glaring at him, doesn't answer. Zeus, God of Thunder. Athena, Goddess of Wisdom. You serve them?
answer: Of course.

question: And Aries, God of War, who blankets his bed with the skins of men he's killed? Briseis pauses, caught in the trap.
answer: All the gods are to be feared and respected. For a long beat they are silent, staring at each other. The air between them is charged with more than mere contention. What do you want here in Troy? You didn't come for the Spartan queen.

question: I want what all men want. I just want it more. Achilles takes an apple and unsheathes a dagger. He tosses the apple in his hand. On the third toss he whips his knife-hand up and across and neatly catches four apple quarters. He offers a quarter to Briseis. Stunned, she slowly shakes her head. Achilles shrugs and eats the sliced apple. I'll tell you a secret-- something they didn't teach you in your temple. The gods envy us. They envy us because we're mortal, because every moment might be our last. Everything is more beautiful for the doomed. He stares at her with such intensity she must look away. You will never be lovelier than you are right now. And we will never be here again. Briseis is quiet for a moment. She rubs the ripe purple grapes on the platter beside her.
answer: I thought you were a dumb brute. She looks into Achilles' eyes. I could have forgiven a dumb brute.

question: Go on. Briseis holds the blade against his skin. Nothing is easier.
answer: Aren't you afraid?

question: Every mortal dies. Today or fifty years from now, what does it matter in the face of eternity?
answer: You'll kill more men if I don't kill you.

question: Many of them. For several seconds she holds the knife to his throat. Finally she puts it down.
answer: May Apollo forgive me. Achilles pulls her closer and they kiss. He slowly slides the robe off her shoulders. Briseis -- eyes closed, lips parted -- trembles as Achilles unveils her. For a moment she hesitates but soon hesitation evaporates and she presses her body against his, kissing his throat, his chest, his hands. Their hunger for each other is stronger than gods and nations.

question: Have the men start loading the ship. We're going home.
answer: You found the girl?

question: I found her.
answer: Is she hurt?

question: Not as badly as those who hurt her. Achilles stares at the sea. Seagulls patrol the skies. Do you miss your wife, Odysseus?
answer: Always.

question: I've never missed anyone in my life. I used to think it was a weakness, needing someone else.
answer: We all need someone else. Right now, Greece needs you.

question: Greece got along fine before I was born and Greece will be Greece long after I'm dead.
answer: I'm not talking about the land. The valleys, the mountains -- they don't care what we do. The men need you. You should have seen the slaughter yesterday.

question: I saw it. And I saw who led the men to slaughter.
answer: Agamemnon... is a proud man. But he knows when he's made a mistake.

question: The man sends you to make his apologies? He doesn't understand honor. What are you doing in thrall to that pig of a king?
answer: The world seems simple to you, my friend. But when you're a king, very few choices are simple. Ithaca cannot afford an enemy like Agamemnon.

question: Am I supposed to fear him?
answer: You don't fear anyone, that's your problem. Fear is useful. Stay, Achilles. You were born for this war.

question: My life is war. Is that what you think?
answer: Am I wrong? Achilles stares at the sea again.

question: A week ago you were right. But things are less simple today.
answer: Women have a way of complicating things. Achilles smiles. He turns to Odysseus and clasps his hand.

question: Of all the kings of Greece, I respect you most. But in this war you're a servant. And I refuse to be a servant any longer.
answer: Sometimes you need to serve in order to lead. I hope you understand that one day.

question: We're going home?
answer: We leave at noon. He tries to enter his tent but Patroclus grabs his arm and blocks his path. Achilles stares at Patroclus' hand. Patroclus releases him but doesn't move out of the way.

question: If Poseidon curses us and our ship goes down, what will I tell the shades in Hades? That I died running from this war, abandoning our countrymen?
answer: Our countrymen?

question: Yes, our country! We're Greek, cousin. I broke bread with these men, I drank their wine, I listened to their jokes. These are our comrades. We cannot desert them. Your feud with Agamemnon is tearing this army apart. And your reputation suffers. The men are talking -- Achilles' eyes narrow as his temper rises.
answer: If my blood wasn't in your veins --

question: But your blood is in my veins.
answer: I gave you an order, cousin. We leave at noon.

question: Am I still your captive?
answer: Captive is a harsh word. You're my guest.

question: In Troy, guests can leave whenever they want.
answer: Strange custom. Achilles takes her hand and inspects her uncalloused palms. You've never worked the fields. Never chopped wood, never carried a milk pail. These are the hands of royalty. Achilles raises his own hands and shows them to her. My hands are gates to the underworld. All my life I've walked with Death. But I grow tired of his company. Come with me to Larissa. A hint of a smile crosses her lips.

question: Larissa. Is that where you're from? It's a pretty name.
answer: I thought I'd never see it again. Before I left home my mother told me my fate.

question: She speaks with the gods?
answer: She knows things. She told me if I stayed home I'd have a long, peaceful life. And if I came to Troy, life would be short... but my name would never be forgotten.

question: And you chose Troy.
answer: But what if Fate brought me here for another purpose? What if I had to go to war to find peace? To find you? She cups his face between her palms, pulls him closer, kisses his lips. For a moment they gaze at each other, until the sounds of WAR CRIES, HORNS, and BATTLE DRUMS fill the air. Achilles raises his head and listens, his face hardening. Briseis, alarmed, watches him.

question: Achilles! Achilles emerges from the ship's cabin and walks to the bow. He descends the gangplank to the beach. Briseis follows. Eudorus bows. Achilles examines his captain. Eudorus is sweaty and dirty, his hands caked with dried blood. His helmet is off but he still wears his armor.
answer: You've been fighting.

question: My lord --
answer: You violated my command.

question: No, my lord. There was a mistake.
answer: A mistake? I ordered the Myrmidons to stand down. You led them into combat?

question: I didn't lead them. Eudorus cannot meet his commander's gaze.
answer: Who did?

question: We thought you did. Now Achilles can tell, staring at his captain's face, that something is very wrong. He looks around the encampment. All the men returning from combat avoid looking at Achilles.
answer: Where's Patroclus?

question: We thought it was you, my lord. We -- he wore your armor. Your shield, your grieves, your helmet. He's dead, my lord.
answer: You're lying.

question: Never, my lord. Never. He looked like you. He even moved like you. We all followed --
answer: Lies.

question: He fought well, my lord. With great courage. But Hector came after him. Achilles' nostrils are flared, his eyes narrowed. If I could have saved him -- Achilles hits Eudorus hard in the mouth. The captain falls to the sand. Achilles looms above him, fists clenched. Eudorus holds his mouth. Blood is already beginning to stream out.
answer: Liar!

question: Where are you taking me? Hector leads her until they reach a bronze-banded oak door. He opens the door, revealing the mouth of a dark tunnel.
answer: You remember how to get here?

question: Yes.
answer: Next time you come, follow this tunnel. There's nowhere to turn, so you can't get lost. Keep walking.

question: Hector --
answer: When you get outside you'll be on the south side of the Scamander River. Follow the river till you see Mount Ida. Keep Ida to your west, walk south, and you'll get to Lyrnessus. The Greeks won't go that far inland.

question: You're frightening me. Hector stares into the darkness of the tunnel. Hector. Why are you telling me this?
answer: If I die --

question: No --
answer: If I die, I don't know how long the city will stand.

question: Don't say that.
answer: If the Greeks get inside the walls, it's over. They'll kill all the men. Doesn't matter how old, they'll pull grandfathers from their beds and carve their lungs out.

question: Please --
answer: Doesn't matter how young. They'll throw the babies from the city walls. Andromache closes her eyes. The women they'll take for slaves. And that will be worse for you than dying.

question: Why are you saying these things?
answer: I want you to be ready. I want you to get our boy, get him, and come here. Save as many others as you can, but you get here, you go down these stairs, and you run. Do you understand? She nods. The flickering flame of the taper throws giant shadows on the stone walls. I killed a boy today. He was too young. Much too young.

question: It never ends. Briseis stares at him for a moment and leaves the tent. Achilles quits his sharpening. Now there is nothing but silence, nothing but a bronze sword for company. Who are you? Priam seems physically hurt by the sight of Achilles. For a moment it seems he will collapse again. But he wills himself onward, walking to Achilles' chair. He sinks to his knees, takes Achilles' hands, and kisses them. Achilles observes all this with curiosity.
answer: I have endured what no one on earth has endured before. I kissed the hands of the man who killed my son.

question: Priam? How did you get in here, old king? The sentries --
answer: I know my own country better than the Greeks, I think.

question: You're a brave man. If Agamemnon knew you were here, he'd have your head on a spit.
answer: Do you really think death frightens me now? I watched my eldest son die, watched you drag his body behind your chariot. Priam stares at Achilles, and for the first time since we've known him, Achilles looks away. Give him back to me. He deserves the honor of a proper burial. You know that. Give him to me.

question: He killed my cousin.
answer: He thought it was you. He defended his country. How many cousins have you killed? How many sons and fathers and brothers and husbands? How many, brave Achilles? I knew your father. He died before his time. But he was lucky not to live long enough to see his son fall. Achilles does not respond. We cannot read his expression. You've taken everything from me. My eldest son, heir to my throne, defender of my kingdom. I can't change what happened. It's the will of the gods. But give me this small mercy. Achilles looks into the old man's eyes. Priam tries to blink back his tears but fails. I loved my boy from the moment he opened his eyes till the moment you closed them. Let me wash his body. Let me say the prayers. Let me place two coins on his eyes for the boatman.

question: If I let you walk out of here, if I let you take him, it doesn't change anything. You're still my enemy in the morning.
answer: You're still my enemy tonight. But even enemies can show respect. Achilles nods.

question: I admire your courage, old man. You're a better king than the one leading this army. Meet me outside in a moment. We'll meet again soon. Your son was the best I've fought. I want you to know that. In my country the funeral games last twelve days.
answer: It's the same in my country.

question: Then no Greek will attack Troy for twelve days. The prince deserves that honor. Achilles, hearing footsteps, turns. Briseis emerges from the shadows. Priam is stunned.
answer: Briseis? Priam wraps his arms around her, thrilled she's alive. We thought you were dead, little swan.

question: You'll be safe behind the Trojan walls. Achilles reaches into his tunic and pulls out the SHELL NECKLACE that Patroclus had worn. He fastens it around her delicate neck, where the purple bruises are still visible. He speaks quietly to her, too softly for Priam to hear. If I hurt you -- it's not what I wanted. You gave me one night of peace in a lifetime of war. She stares up at him, her young face mapped with conflicting emotions. Finally, Achilles turns to Priam. Go. No one will stop you, you have my word. Priam gets in the chariot. Briseis still looks at Achilles.
answer: Come, my girl. Priam reaches down and helps her onto the chariot. He seizes the reins and they're off, the Myrmidons escorting them to safety. Achilles stares at Briseis until she's gone.

question: Wily Odysseus. You've found a way to make the sheep invite the wolves over for dinner.
answer: This is war.

question: Agamemnon will kill them all. Men, women, children -- all of them. You know that. Achilles walks away. Odysseus follows him.
answer: I'm the king of Ithaca, not Troy. My loyalty is to Ithaca. If this plan works, the war ends in a night. And my men can sail home to their wives. Achilles keeps walking, Odysseus pacing after him. It's not Troy you're worried about, is it? It's one Trojan. One Trojan girl.

question: I've always liked you. But if that girl dies because of your plan, you will never sail home to your wife. Achilles turns and leaves. Odysseus takes a deep breath. Eudorus. Forgive me. Eudorus blinks. No one has ever heard these words from Achilles' mouth before. I should never have struck you. You've been a loyal friend all your life.
answer: I hope I never disappoint you again.

question: Rouse the men. You're taking them home.
answer: Aren't you coming with us?

question: I've got one more battle to fight. Eudorus hesitates, watching his lord. Finally:
answer: She's worth fighting for. We'll march behind you.

question: All that's left is the slaughter. I don't want to see my men fouled with children's blood. Go, Eudorus. This is the last order I give you. After a long pause, Eudorus bows deeply to his commander.
answer: Fighting for you has been my life's honor. Achilles grips his lieutenant's shoulder and strides away.

question: We have to run.
answer: Where?

question: I'll show you. Paris looks at Helen.
answer: Come, my love. Come with us.

question: I stay.
answer: No --

question: My father will never abandon the city. I can't leave him.
answer: The city is dead! They're burning it to the ground! Paris looks at the huddled refugees. They're a timid lot, terrified and weak. AENEAS looks stronger and braver than the rest. He's supporting his ELDERLY FATHER.

question: I'll find her. Andromache kisses him. She turns and leads the way through the tunnel. The Trojans follow. Aeneas bows to Paris and helps his father as their long journey begins.
answer: I'll stay with you. Paris pushes her gently toward the door.

question: Go.
answer: Don't leave me. Please don't leave me.

question: How could you love me if I ran now?
answer: Please --

question: Come with me. Before she can answer her eyes go wide. She sees Paris, in the upper garden, notching an arrow. Come. I'll protect you. Paris pulls back the catgut string. Briseis screams:
answer: No! Paris fires. Briseis's scream distracts him -- the arrow sails off course, hitting Achilles above his heel, tearing through the tendon. Achilles staggers, turns, and sees Paris. Achilles snarls and heads for him. Paris shoots again. Achilles tries to dodge but the torn tendon in his heel slows him down. The arrow rips through his side. Achilles keeps limping forward. Stop! Paris! Stop! Stop! Achilles keeps coming. Paris reaches for another arrow. His quiver is empty. Aeneas has his sword. The palace around them is burning, lighting their faces. Blood pours from Achilles' wounds. The arrow shafts stick out of him. Any other man would have already fallen. But he keeps coming, relentless, his face a mask of grim purpose. Briseis runs in front of her cousin Paris and shields him with her body. Achilles lifts his bloody sword. No more. Briseis does not move. For several seconds the great warrior and the young girl stare at each other. No more killing. Achilles looks at the seashell necklace she wears. No more. Achilles raises his sword and brings it down hard, burying its bronze blade in the soil of the garden.

question: No more. He reaches out and rubs the shells of her necklace. My mother made this necklace. You have to get out.
answer: Shh.

question: Get out. She kisses his lips, running her fingers across his jaw.
answer: There's no way out. Achilles stares at Paris.

question: There's always a way out for the princes. Paris tries to lift Briseis to her feet but she refuses. Briseis. She leans closer. He's losing too much blood, his strength is fading, but he summons his remaining energy to speak. I chose this night... but you will see the sun again. I want you to live. Her face is full of sorrow and love. He touches her lips, his fingers trembling as his body fails. She kisses him. Live. She doesn't want to go but he pushes her gently away. Finally she nods.
answer: Because of you.
